It also provides disabling forking wich should be discussed.

issue.title: Introduce support for retrying failed flaky tests

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

Feature request to add native support to rerun failing flaky tests

**Feature request** 

Is there any plan to support the ability of rerunning failed flaky tests? For example, it would be great to have something like `@Flaky(rerun=3)`, which would rerun a failing flaky test up to n times.

In the *past*, in Surefire/Failsafe we could use `rerunFailingTestsCount`. However, it does not work in JUnit 5. As JUnit 5.0.0 was released nearly 1 year ago, it is unclear if and when it will be supported in Maven.

And, even if it will be supported in Maven in the future, it could be good to have a special annotation to specify that only some tests are expected to be flaky, and not *all* of them.

At the moment, the workaround is to stick with JUnit 4, which is a kind of a shame as JUnit 5  has a lot of interesting features :(  (which I can only use in projects with no flaky tests)

Related [SO question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46181026/junit5-how-to-repeat-failed-test).

body:
I have a similar requirement for Quarkus testing, with regards to skipping @BeforeAll and @AfterAll methods. 

I can generate a Proxy of a test and use this to redirect test methods into test instance defined in a new ClassLoader, however BeforeAll and AfterAll are always invoked on the original test Class. 

If I did not have to invoke Invocation.proceed() I could just invoke these methods on my actual test directly, and then avoid invocation on the test class in the original ClassLoader.

issue.title: java.lang.IllegalStateException: This method is normally automatically..... in IT tests

labels.name: pinned
labels.description: Issue will never be marked as stale

body: @loicmathieu Have you considered writing a TestEngine instead? I don't know how your execution in a separate VM works, but I could imagine supporting arbitrary Jupiter extensions.

The TestEngine approach would not work for my use case, as I would want to delegate all the logic to Jupiter, and having it on the class path would result in problems (I think Arquillian attempted this and ran into similar issues).

I need a way to execute a test inside an isolated ClassLoader, and I can do almost everything by creating a proxy that extends the actual test class and forwarding all the invocations, except for @BeforeAll and @AfterAll because they are static. 

The best I can do is have an invocation on both the class in the bootstrap class loader and in the isolated class loader, which will work sometimes but not if they are doing things like listening on a port which would conflict.

If I could prevent the invocation hitting the original class then I could just directly invoke these methods on the class in my isolated ClassLoader.

Since we support multiple `InvocationInterceptors` that get chained we have to decide what to do if one of them that's not last in the list decides to skip the invocation. We could either allow that and not call the remaining interceptors or only allow the last interceptor in the chain to skip. I lean towards the first option.
**Team Decision:** Implement the first option and add debug logging when skip was called.
@loicmathieu Would you still like to submit a PR for this one?
